facts.text: Appeal preferred against judgment of High Court of Punjab at Simla dated 18th June 1951

anchor.surface_text: Mehr Chand Mahajan, C.J. This appeal is preferred against the judgment of the High Court of Punjab at Simla, dated 18th June, 1951,

facts.text: High Court answered two referred questions in the affirmative

anchor.surface_text: delivered on a reference under section 66 of the Indian Income-tax Act whereby the High Court answered the following two referred questions in the affirmative - Whether on a proper companys

facts.text: Assessee is a public limited company formed in 1917

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, a public limited companypany, which is the appellant before us, was formed in 1917 with the following objects To undertake and carry on the general

facts.text: Objects include general business of commission agents, insurance agents, commercial agents, bankers, merchants, deal in money, shares, bills, hundis, securities

anchor.surface_text: business and trade of companymission agents, insurance agents, companymercial agents, export and import agents, clearing and forwarding or house or land agents, bankers and merchants of every description or any other work calculated directly or indirectly to benefit the companypany, to raise or take up or advance moneys on loan, deposit, debentures, securities or otherwise, and to deal in money, numberes, bills, hundis and other securities.

facts.text: Objects include acquire lands, buildings, machinery, property; encourage, finance, manage commercial industrial undertakings

anchor.surface_text: To take on lease, trust or in exchange and otherwise acquire lands, buildings, machinery manufactures and other property. To encourage, originate, finance or undertake the management of companymercial and industrial undertakings, and to help or to support any charitable, educational or public objects and institution.

facts.text: Sarswati Sugar Syndicate Ltd. incorporated in 1933

anchor.surface_text: In 1933, another public limited companypany was incorporated by the name of Sarswati Sugar Syndicate Ltd., hereinafter called the sugar companypany.

facts.text: Lala Kishan Prasad was managing director of assessee company

anchor.surface_text: Lala Kishan Prasad, managing director of the assessee companypany, entered into an agreement with the sugar companypany in March, 1933,

facts.text: Agreement in March 1933: assessee to invest Rs. 5,00,000 in sugar company for managing agency of third mill

anchor.surface_text: entered into an agreement with the sugar companypany in March, 1933, whereby the assessee companypany was to invest Rs. 5,00,000 in the sugar companypany in lieu of which it was to be given the managing agency of the third mill of the sugar companypany - number in existence at the time but expected to be erected in 1933 -

facts.text: Investment conditional on sugar company receiving other applications for shares of at least Rs. 7,00,000

anchor.surface_text: when such mill was erected, on the same terms as given by the sugar companypany to other managing agents of their two other existing mills. The investment of Rs. 5,00,000 by the assessee companypany was made companyditional on the sugar companypany receiving other applications for shares to the tune of at least Rs. 7,00,000.

facts.text: If third mill not erected, sugar company to pay assessee Rs. 15,000 as commission on moneys invested

anchor.surface_text: It was further agreed that if the third mill was number erected then the sugar companypany was to pay to the assessee companypany Rs. 15,000 as companymission upon the moneys invested by them in shares.

facts.text: Modification: assessee subscribe to shares worth Rs. 3,00,000, remaining Rs. 2,00,000 by friends

anchor.surface_text: There was subsequently a modification to the effect that the assessee companypany would themselves subscribed to shares worth Rs. 3,00,000 and the remaining shares of Rs. 2,00,000 will be subscribed to by their friends.

facts.text: 3,000 shares of value Rs. 3,00,000 purchased by assessee, share certificates issued by sugar company

anchor.surface_text: 3,000 shares of the value of Rs. 3,00,000 were purchased and share certificates duly issued by the sugar companypany to the assessee companypany.

facts.text: Lala Kishan Prasad made director of sugar company

anchor.surface_text: Lala Kishan Prasad was made a director of the sugar companypany.

facts.text: Third mill not erected, agreement for managing agency fell through

anchor.surface_text: The third mill was, however, number erected and the agreement about acquiring the managing agency fell through.

facts.text: Lala Kishan Prasad died in December 1940

anchor.surface_text: Lala Kishan Prasad died in December, 1940, and the assessee companypany decided to sell all the shares in 1941.

facts.text: Assessee decided to sell all shares in 1941

anchor.surface_text: and the assessee companypany decided to sell all the shares in 1941.

facts.text: 2,000 shares sold first, excess Rs. 20,000 over original cost

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that 2,000 shares were first sold and brought an excess amount of Rs. 20,000 over the original companyt price.

facts.text: Remaining 1,000 shares sold in 1943, excess Rs. 2,26,700

anchor.surface_text: The remaining 1,000 shares were sold in 1943 and they brought in an excess realisation of Rs. 2,26,700.

facts.text: Excesses taxed by Income-tax Officer Ambala as revenue receipts: Rs.20,000 in 1942-43, Rs.2,26,700 in 1944-45

anchor.surface_text: Both these amounts were taxed by the Income-tax Officer, Ambala, as revenue receipts, the first in the assessment year 1942-43 and the second in 1944-45.

facts.text: Assessee contention that excess was capital appreciation not accepted by ITO

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companypanys companytention that the excess was in the nature of capital appreciation was number accepted.

facts.text: Order confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Appellate Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: This order was companyfirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: ITAT referred two questions to High Court at instance of assessee

anchor.surface_text: The latter then referred at the instance of the assessee companypany the two questions set out above to the High Court of Punjab.

facts.text: Assessee claimed exemption under section 4(3)(vii) as casual non-recurring not from business

anchor.surface_text: The assessee companypany claimed exemption from tax in respect of the aforesaid amounts on the ground that they were number receipts arising from business and were of a casual and number-recurring nature. This claim was founded upon the exemption companytained in section 4, sub- section  3   vii ,

facts.text: Agreed that receipts were casual and non-recurring

anchor.surface_text: It was also agreed that the two receipts were of a casual and number-recurring nature and this fact is numbericed by the High Court in their judgment.

facts.text: Shares purchased before period in section 12B

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly the first portion of this clause does number apply to the case for the shares were purchased before the period mentioned in section 12B.

facts.text: Revenue argued MoA allows dealing in shares as securities, but High Court negatived and respondent conceded

anchor.surface_text: An argument was put forward at one stage on behalf of the revenue that the assessee companypany, by virtue of its memorandum of association, was allowed to deal in money, numberes, bills, hundis and other securities and that the shares which were purchased and sold fell within the category of securities. The High Court negatived this companytention and Mr. Joshi on behalf of the respondent has also companyceded this point.

facts.text: High Court held transaction to obtain managing agency and directorship within object to undertake management of commercial undertaking

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held., however, that the intention and purpose of the adventure was to obtain the managing agency of the sugar mill and the directorship in the sugar companypany and this fell within the object  c  to undertake the management of companymercial undertaken

facts.text: It is admitted that beyond this isolated transaction, assessee did not deal in shares

anchor.surface_text: number is it denied that beyond this isolated transaction of purchase and sale the assessee companypany did number deal in shares.

facts.text: Letter dated 14th March 1933 embodies terms of agreement

anchor.surface_text: The letter dated 14th March, 1933, which admittedly embodies the terms of the agreement between Lala Kishan Prasad and the directors of the sugar companypany

facts.text: Assessee replied on 17th March 1933: subscribe Rs.3L own, Rs.2L to friends

anchor.surface_text: To this letter the assessee companypany replied on 17th March, 1933, that they would themselves subscribed to shares worth Rs. 3,00,000 and the remaining shares worth Rs. 2,00,000 they will sell to their friends.

holdings.text: The circumstance whether a transaction is or is not within its powers has no bearing on the nature of the transaction, or on the question whether the profits arising therefrom are capital accretion or revenue income.

anchor.surface_text: The circumstance whether a transaction is or is not within its powers has no bearing on the nature of the transaction, or on the question whether the profits arising therefrom are capital accretion or revenue income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes relevance of corporate powers under MoA from determination of capital vs revenue nature for tax purposes.

holdings.text: The memorandum of association of the assessee company did not authorise it to purchase or sell shares as dealers and beyond this isolated transaction the assessee company did not deal in shares.

anchor.surface_text: The exact nature of the business which the assessee company was doing is admittedly not clear from the record but it is not denied that the memorandum of association of the assessee company did not authorise it to purchase and or sell shares as dealers nor is it denied that beyond this isolated transaction of purchase and sale the assessee company did not deal in shares.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted and not denied on record; High Court rejected revenue argument and respondent conceded.

holdings.text: The object of the assessee company in buying shares was purely to obtain the managing agency of the third mill as an asset of an enduring nature and there was from the inception no intention whatever to re-sell the shares or otherwise deal in them.

anchor.surface_text: It seems that the object of the assessee company in buying shares was purely to obtain the managing agency of the third mill which no doubt would have been an asset of an enduring nature and would have brought them profits but there was from the inception no intention whatever on the part of the assessee company to re-sell the shares either at a profit or otherwise deal in them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intention determined from circumstances: purpose to secure agency frustrated by non-erection of mill leading to sale; isolated nature supports investment.

holdings.text: Out of Rs. 3,00,000 invested, it was not the case that only Rs. 1,00,000 was for managing agency and remaining for profit; respondent's split interpretation incorrect.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that this would be a correct interpretation of the terms of the agreement. The letter dated 14th March, 1933, which admittedly embodies the terms of the agreement between Lala Kishan Prasad and the directors of the sugar company clearly says that the assessee company would invest Rs. 5,00,000 of their own.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects partial profit motive; whole investment conditional on agency per agreement terms.

holdings.text: The transaction was one and indivisible and the sole object of the agreement was to acquire the managing agency as an asset of a permanent character in order to have a hold on the directors.

anchor.surface_text: To this letter the assessee company replied on 17th March, 1933, that they would themselves subscribe to shares worth Rs. 3,00,000 and the remaining shares worth Rs. 2,00,000 they will sell to their friends. These two letters leave no doubt that the transaction was one and indivisible and the sole object of the agreement was to acquire the managing agency as an asset of a permanent character in order to have a hold on the directors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letters of 14th and 17th March 1933 read harmoniously show unified purpose for entire investment to secure agency.

holdings.text: The investment of the money in the purchase of shares was of a capital nature and the profits arising out of the sale of the shares were accretions to capital and were not liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: After conceding that the taking up of the shares of Rs. 3,00,000 by the assessee company in the sugar company was an essential part of the arrangement arrived at, the only reasonable conclusion to which the High Court should have come was that the investment of the money in the purchase of shares was of a capital nature and the profits arising out of the sale of the shares in the circumstances of this case were accretions to capital and were not liable to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying test for adventure in trade: no trading intent, capital investment for agency; profits capital accretion.

holdings.text: The purchase of shares to the tune of Rs. 3,00,000 was an investment and not an adventure and the two sums which were taxed were not in the nature of income from business and were therefore not liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly reverse the decision of the High Court and hold that the purchase of shares to the tune of Rs. 3,00,000 was an investment and not an adventure and the two sums which were taxed were not in the nature of income from business and were therefore not liable to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reverses High Court on referred questions; integrates findings on intention, agreement, isolated nature to hold not business income but exempt capital under s4(3)(vii).

anchor.surface_text: The exact nature of the business which the assessee company was doing is admittedly not clear from the record but it is not denied that the memorandum of association of the assessee company did not authorise it to purchase and or sell shares as dealers nor is it denied that beyond this isolated transaction of purchase and sale the assessee company did not deal in shares.

anchor.surface_text: It seems that the object of the assessee company in buying shares was purely to obtain the managing agency of the third mill which no doubt would have been an asset of an enduring nature and would have brought them profits but there was from the inception no intention whatever on the part of the assessee company to re-sell the shares either at a profit or otherwise deal in them.

anchor.surface_text: To this letter the assessee company replied on 17th March, 1933, that they would themselves subscribe to shares worth Rs. 3,00,000 and the remaining shares worth Rs. 2,00,000 they will sell to their friends. anchor.surface_text: After conceding that the taking up of the shares of Rs. 3,00,000 by the assessee company in the sugar company was an essential part of the arrangement arrived at, the only reasonable conclusion to which the High Court should have come was that the investment of the money in the purchase of shares was of a capital nature and the profits arising out of the sale of the shares in the circumstances of this case were accretions to capital and were not liable to tax.
